questions.text: VEP in optic neuropathy is?

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in latency and decrease in amplitude

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease in latency and increase in amplitude

questions.correct_answer: C. Increase in latency and decrease in amplitude
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increase in latency and decrease in amplitude

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Increase in Latency Only :
  • • Option A
  • • Increase in Latency Only
  • • Latency refers to the time it takes for a signal to travel from the eye to the visual cortex in the brain . An increase in latency means the signal is slower than normal , which can happen in optic neuropathy due to demyelination or other nerve damage . However, this option does not consider changes in amplitude, which are also important in the context of optic nerve damage.
  • • Latency refers to the time it takes for a signal to travel from the eye to the visual cortex in the brain .
  • • Latency refers to the time it takes for a signal to travel from the eye
  • • visual cortex in the brain
  • • An increase in latency means the signal is slower than normal , which can happen in optic neuropathy due to demyelination or other nerve damage .
  • • increase in latency
  • • signal is slower than normal
  • • optic neuropathy
  • • demyelination or other nerve damage
  • • However, this option does not consider changes in amplitude, which are also important in the context of optic nerve damage.
  • • Option B . Increase in Amplitude Only :
  • • Option B
  • • Increase in Amplitude Only
  • • Amplitude in VEP represents the strength or intensity of the signal reaching the visual cortex . An increase in amplitude is not typically associated with optic neuropathy . In fact, optic nerve damage more commonly leads to a decrease in amplitude due to reduced signal transmission efficiency.
  • • Amplitude in VEP represents the strength or intensity of the signal reaching the visual cortex .
  • • Amplitude in VEP
  • • strength or intensity of the signal reaching the visual cortex
  • • An increase in amplitude is not typically associated with optic neuropathy . In fact, optic nerve damage more commonly leads to a decrease in amplitude due to reduced signal transmission efficiency.
  • • increase in amplitude
  • • not
  • • associated with optic neuropathy
  • • Option D . Decrease in Latency and Increase in Amplitude :
  • • Option D
  • • Decrease in Latency and Increase in Amplitude
  • • A decrease in latency would imply faster-than-normal signal transmission , which is not characteristic of optic neuropathy. Similarly, an increase in amplitude is not typical of optic neuropathy , where signal strength usually diminishes. This pattern is contrary to what is expected in optic nerve damage and is not a typical finding in optic neuropathy.
  • • A decrease in latency would imply faster-than-normal signal transmission , which is not characteristic of optic neuropathy.
  • • decrease in latency would imply faster-than-normal signal transmission
  • • Similarly, an increase in amplitude is not typical of optic neuropathy , where signal strength usually diminishes.
  • • an increase in amplitude is not typical of optic neuropathy
  • • This pattern is contrary to what is expected in optic nerve damage and is not a typical finding in optic neuropathy.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that in optic neuropathy , Visual Evoked Potentials typically show an increase in latency and a decrease in amplitude, reflecting delayed and weakened transmission of visual signals due to optic nerve damage.

questions.text: A patient presented with bilateral loss of vision with normal pupillary light reflex. Ocular evaluation was found to be normal. VEP shows extinguished response. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cortical blindness

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Malingering: wilful ‘blind’ behaviour, i.e. feigning of symptoms. On clinical examination, no ocular or neuro-ophthalmic findings are detectable which can account for the symptoms. Multiple tests like Prism test, Worth four-dot test are devised to diagnose this condition.
  • • Option A. Malingering:
  • • ‘blind’ behaviour,
  • • feigning of symptoms.
  • • no ocular or neuro-ophthalmic findings are detectable
  • • Option C. Retrobulbar neuritis : Definitive or relative afferent pupillary defect would be present .
  • • Option C. Retrobulbar neuritis
  • • Definitive
  • • relative afferent pupillary defect would be present
  • • Option D. Hysterical blindness: Unlike malingering, there is little or no insight into their infirmity in these cases and may sometimes display a complete lack of concern over their incapacitating symptoms (la belle indifference). May be associated with blepharospasm and lacrimation. Visual fields are concentrically contracted.
  • • Option D.
  • • Hysterical blindness:
  • • there is little or no insight into their infirmity in these cases and may sometimes display a complete lack of concern over their incapacitating symptoms

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Cortical blindness is characterized by an inability to see despite normal eyes and pupillary reflexes . The disrupted cortical processing is evidenced by extinguished VEPs.

  • ➤ pupillary reflexes
  • ➤ disrupted cortical processing
  • ➤ extinguished VEPs.

questions.text: Which of the following types of amblyopia is associated with worst prognosis?

questions.text: A 65-year-old man came to the ophthalmologist with a complaint of gradually increasing blurring of vision in both his eyes since 1 year. Ans. C) Vascularity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The lens is covered by a single layer of epithelial cells on its anterior surface . These cells are essential for lens growth and transparency . They help regulate water and ion balance in the lens and produce lens fibers , which are crucial for maintaining lens clarity .

  • • Option B. Lens has natural auto oxidation mechanism .
  • • Option B.
  • • natural auto oxidation mechanism
  • • Option D. The lens contains ion channels and pumps that help maintain its dehydration and precise ion balance , which are essential for lens transparency . Disruption in this pump mechanism can lead to cataract formation .
  • • Option D.

  • • dehydration
  • • precise ion balance
  • • lens transparency

  • • cataract formation

questions.text: A 28-year-old sexually active female presents to the emergency department with redness, purulent discharge, and marked eyelid swelling in the left eye. On further evaluation, the diagnosis of gonococcal conjunctivitis is confirmed. Which of the following complications is the patient at the highest risk for if left untreated?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Cataract Formation: While cataract formation is a potential complication of ocular infections , it is not the primary concern in gonococcal conjunctivitis. Corneal involvement and subsequent complications are more common in this condition.
  • • Option B. Cataract Formation:
  • • cataract formation
  • • ocular infections
  • • Corneal involvement
  • • Option C. Retinal Detachment: Retinal detachment is not typically associated with gonococcal conjunctivitis. It occurs due to the separation of the retina from the underlying tissue and is not a common sequela of this type of conjunctivitis.
  • • Option C. Retinal Detachment:
  • • separation
  • • retina
  • • underlying tissue
  • • Option D. Optic Neuritis: Optic neuritis refers to inflammation of the optic nerve and can lead to vision impairment . It is not a direct complication of gonococcal conjunctivitis. Complications in gonococcal conjunctivitis usually involve the anterior segment of the eye , such as the cornea .
  • • Option D. Optic Neuritis:
  • • inflammation
  • • optic nerve
  • • vision impairment
  • • gonococcal conjunctivitis
  • • involve
  • • anterior segment
  • • eye
  • • cornea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The patient with gonococcal conjunctivitis is at the highest risk for the complication of Corneal ulceration . This complication can result in significant vision loss and highlights the importance of early diagnosis and treatment of gonococcal conjunctivitis to prevent severe ocular damage .

questions.text: A patient undergoing perimetry has the following visual field defect. What is the pupillary abnormality expected in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Wernicke’s pupil

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Argyll Robertson Pupil: This is a condition where pupils are small and irregular but do not constrict when exposed to bright light (light-near dissociation). They do, however, constrict with accommodation . It is classically associated with neurosyphilis, particularly tabes dorsalis, and does not have a direct correlation with homonymous hemianopia.
  • • Option A
  • • Argyll Robertson Pupil:
  • • condition where pupils are small and irregular but do not constrict
  • • exposed to bright light
  • • constrict with accommodation
  • • Option B. Adie’s Pupil: Also known as tonic pupil , it is usually unilateral and is larger than the other pupil . It reacts poorly to light but may have a better near response. This condition is caused by damage to the postganglionic fibers of the parasympathetic innervation of the eye and is not related to visual field defects.
  • • Option B.
  • • Adie’s Pupil:
  • • tonic pupil
  • • unilateral and is larger than the other pupil
  • • condition is caused by damage to the postganglionic fibers
  • • Option C. Marcus Gunn Pupil: Also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), it is a sign of asymmetrical optic nerve dysfunction . It is detected using the swinging flashlight test . However, in homonymous hemianopia, the optic nerve function is typically preserved until the optic chiasm, so a Marcus Gunn pupil is not expected.
  • • Option C.
  • • Marcus Gunn Pupil:
  • • relative afferent pupillary defect
  • • sign of asymmetrical optic nerve dysfunction
  • • detected using the swinging flashlight test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a case of right homonymous hemianopia , the lesion lies at the level of left optic tract , and the pupillary abnormality seen in these cases will be Wernicke’s pupil .

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of a blow-out fracture of orbit?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Exophthalmos

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Diplopia : It is a common symptom of blow-out fractures , often resulting from impaired movement of the affected eye due to muscle entrapment or nerve damage.
  • • Option B.
  • • Diplopia
  • • common symptom of blow-out fractures
  • • resulting from impaired movement
  • • Option C. Enophthalmos : This is the posterior displacement of the eye within the orbit , leading to a sunken appearance. It is a characteristic sign of blow-out fractures. The increase in the orbital volume caused by the fracture allows the eyeball to sink backward.
  • • Option C.
  • • Enophthalmos
  • • posterior displacement of the eye within the orbit
  • • sunken appearance.
  • • Option D. Infraorbital nerve anesthesia : This refers to a loss of sensation in the area supplied by the infraorbital nerve , typically the lower eyelid, cheek, and upper lip . It can occur in blow-out fractures if the fracture involves the infraorbital groove or canal, where the nerve runs.
  • • Option D.
  • • Infraorbital nerve anesthesia
  • • loss of sensation in the area supplied by the infraorbital nerve
  • • lower eyelid, cheek, and upper lip

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Enophthalmos, not exophthalmos , is a sign of blow-out fracture of the orbit . Blow-out fractures typically increase orbital volume , allowing the eyeball to sink backward , leading to enophthalmos , rather than protruding forward as in exophthalmos.

questions.text: A 59-year-old male patient came with the complaint of shortness of breath. On examination, fullness in the right supraclavicular region is observed. On ocular examination, right pupil is constricted. Which of the following is not a feature of the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Heterochromia Iridis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Ptosis: This is a hallmark feature of Horner's syndrome. It occurs due to paralysis of the Müller's muscle, a sympathetically innervated muscle in the eyelid, leading to a slight drooping of the upper eyelid.
  • • Option A. Ptosis:
  • • hallmark feature of Horner's syndrome.
  • • Option B. Anhidrosis: This refers to the absence or decrease in sweating on the affected side of the face . It is a feature of Horner's syndrome due to the disruption of sympathetic nerves that innervate sweat glands.
  • • Option B. Anhidrosis:
  • • refers to the absence or decrease in sweating on the affected side of the face
  • • Option D. Enophthalmos: This refers to the posterior displacement of the eyeball within the orbit, leading to a sunken appearance. While mild enophthalmos can be associated with Horner's syndrome due to the lack of sympathetic tone to the orbitalis muscle, it is not as prominent or diagnostic as the other features.
  • • Option D. Enophthalmos:
  • • refers to the posterior displacement of the eyeball within the orbit, leading to a sunken appearance.
  • • Conclusion:
  • • Conclusion:
  • • Heterochromia iridis is not a typical feature of adult onset Horner's syndrome. The classic triad of Horner's syndrome consists of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis, with enophthalmos being a less prominent associated feature.
  • • Heterochromia iridis
  • • not a typical feature of adult onset Horner's syndrome.
  • • triad of Horner's syndrome
  • • ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis, with enophthalmos

Orbital involvement in non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma usually indicates a systemic disease rather than a primary orbital tumor.

  • • lymphatic system.

  • • most commonly seen in children

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric emergency with complaints of 5 days of progressive left facial swelling and fever. On ocular inspection, left periorbital oedema, erythema and discharge are noted. On examination, left eye showed decrease in visual acuity, and the pupil showed relative afferent pupillary defect. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. AV Malformation (Arteriovenous Malformation) : This is an abnormal connection between arteries and veins , bypassing the capillary system . It can cause swelling and other issues due to altered blood flow , but it typically does not present with infection-like symptoms (fever, discharge) or a rapid onset of visual changes and RAPD.
  • • Option A.
  • • AV Malformation (Arteriovenous Malformation)
  • • abnormal connection between arteries and veins
  • • bypassing the capillary system
  • • cause swelling
  • • altered blood flow
  • • does not present with infection-like symptoms
  • • Option C. Retinoblastoma : A malignant tumor of the retina , common in children . It usually presents with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) and may cause vision loss . However, retinoblastoma does not typically cause fever , periorbital edema, or erythema, which are indicative of an infectious process.
  • • Option C.
  • • Retinoblastoma
  • • malignant tumor of the retina
  • • children
  • • white pupillary reflex
  • • cause vision loss
  • • retinoblastoma
  • • not typically cause fever
  • • Option D. Neuroblastoma : A cancer that develops from immature nerve cells , mostly occurring in children . It can present with various symptoms depending on the site of the tumor but is unlikely to cause localized periorbital edema , erythema, and discharge without other systemic or neurological symptoms.
  • • Option D.
  • • Neuroblastoma
  • • cancer that develops from immature nerve cells
  • • children
  • • site of the tumor
  • • unlikely
  • • cause localized periorbital edema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a pediatric patient presenting with fever , progressive facial swelling , periorbital edema , erythema , discharge , decreased visual acuity , and RAPD , the most probable diagnosis is Orbital Cellulitis , an infectious condition characterized by inflammation and infection of the orbital tissues, often requiring prompt medical intervention.

questions.text: In a 35-year-old woman with a history of right eye ptosis for 6 months, the eyelids appear asymmetrical, and the ptosis fluctuates throughout the day, worsening in the evening. The fatigability test shows positive results. Which of the following tests is not helpful in diagnosing the condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Snap back test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Edrophonium Test : This test is useful in diagnosing MG . Edrophonium, a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor , temporarily increases the availability of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction , leading to an improvement in muscle strength in patients with MG.

  • • useful in diagnosing MG

  • • increases the availability of acetylcholine
  • • neuromuscular junction
  • • Option B. Ice Pack Test : This test is also helpful in MG . Cooling improves neuromuscular transmission , and thus, application of an ice pack on the eyelids can temporarily improve ptosis in MG.
  • • Option B.
  • • Ice Pack Test
  • • test is also helpful in MG
  • • Cooling
  • • neuromuscular transmission
  • • Option D. Electromyography (EMG) : EMG, especially single-fiber EMG, is a key diagnostic tool in MG . It measures the electrical activity of muscles and can detect the characteristic patterns of neuromuscular transmission failure seen in MG.
  • • Option D.
  • • Electromyography (EMG)
  • • single-fiber EMG,
  • • diagnostic tool in MG

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient who is on ATT came to the OPD with complaints of blurring of vision and impairment in colour vision. On carrying out perimetry, bilateral centrocecal scotoma is noted. Which of the following drug may be responsible?

questions.text: When light is flashed onto one eye, both the eyes’ pupils constrict as a response. This is known as the pupillary light reflex. Where is the center for this reflex located?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Midbrain

Explanation:

  • • Option A : Pons : Pontine centres are involved in optokinetic nystagmus . Pontine lesions cause dolls eye movement.
  • • Option A
  • • Pons
  • • Pontine centres
  • • optokinetic nystagmus
  • • dolls eye movement.
  • • Option D: Cerebellum - Cerebellum is involved in integration and coordination of optokinetic nystagmus . Characteristics of cerebellar nystagmus include:
  • • Option D: Cerebellum
  • • integration and coordination of optokinetic nystagmus
  • • Direction : It is typically horizontal, but can also be vertical or rotary. The direction of the nystagmus may change depending on the direction of gaze. Gaze-Evoked Nystagmus : This form of nystagmus becomes more pronounced when the patient looks to the side. It is due to the failure of the cerebellum to hold steady gaze, leading to a drift of the eyes back to the central position, followed by a corrective saccade. Intensity and Amplitude : The intensity and amplitude of the nystagmus can increase with the degree of lateral gaze and decrease or disappear with gaze towards the midline. Associated Symptoms : Patients with cerebellar nystagmus may also exhibit other signs of cerebellar dysfunction, such as ataxia, dysarthria, and tremor.
  • • Direction : It is typically horizontal, but can also be vertical or rotary. The direction of the nystagmus may change depending on the direction of gaze.

  • • Gaze-Evoked Nystagmus

questions.text: In the lens, what is/are the pathway(s) involved in the metabolism of glucose?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The Krebs cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle or TCA cycle ) is a key metabolic pathway that generates energy through the oxidation of acetyl-CoA derived from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins . However, in the lens , the Krebs cycle plays a minimal role because the lens operates in a relatively hypoxic environment and relies more on anaerobic glycolysis for its energy requirements .
  • • Option A.
  • • citric acid cycle

  • • relatively hypoxic environment
  • • relies
  • • anaerobic glycolysis
  • • energy requirements
  • • Option B. Hexose Monophosphate Pathway (HMP Pathway) , also known as the pentose phosphate pathway , is an important metabolic pathway in the lens . It provides the lens with NADPH , which is crucial for maintaining reduced glutathione levels . Reduced glutathione is vital for protecting the lens against oxidative stress , thus helping maintain its transparency and preventing cataract formation .
  • • Option B. Hexose Monophosphate Pathway (HMP Pathway)
  • • pentose phosphate pathway
  • • metabolic pathway
  • • lens
  • • NADPH
  • • crucial
  • • reduced glutathione levels
  • • Reduced glutathione
  • • protecting
  • • against oxidative stress
  • • maintain
  • • transparency
  • • preventing cataract formation
  • • Option C. Sorbitol Pathway , also known as the polyol pathway , involves the conversion of glucose to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase . In the lens, this pathway becomes particularly active in hyperglycemic conditions , such as in diabetes , and can lead to the accumulation of sorbitol . Excessive accumulation of sorbitol can cause osmotic stress , leading to lens swelling , opacification , and cataract formation .
  • • Option C. Sorbitol Pathway

  • • cataract formation

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with complaints of defective vision in the right eye associated with erythropsia and cyanopsia. On examination it was seen that his pupil was jet black and the Purkinje image test revealed only two images. What is likely to be the conclusion after performing retinoscopy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) High Hypermetropia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Low Hypermetropia : Hypermetropia ( farsightedness ) occurs when the eye is too short or the lens is too weak , causing light to focus behind the retina . However, the absence of the lens in aphakia leads to a much more significant refractive error than what would be classified as "low" hypermetropia .
  • • Option A
  • • Low Hypermetropia
  • • farsightedness
  • • too short
  • • too weak
  • • light
  • • focus behind the retina
  • • "low" hypermetropia
  • • Option B . Low Myopia : Myopia (near-sightedness) is when the eye is too long or the lens is too strong , causing light to focus in front of the retina . Aphakia does not typically result in myopia, as the removal of the lens significantly reduces the eye's refractive power.
  • • Option B
  • • Low Myopia
  • • too long
  • • too strong
  • • front of the retina
  • • Option D. High Myopia : As mentioned, aphakia generally does not lead to myopia. The condition results in a loss of refractive power , not an excess of it, which would be necessary to cause high myopia.
  • • Option D. High Myopia
  • • loss of refractive power

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In aphakic patients, where the natural lens of the eye is absent , retinoscopy typically reveals high hypermetropia due to the significant reduction in the eye's refractive power .
  • ➤ absent

questions.text: When was NPCB established in India?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1976

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) was launched in India in 1976 with the goal of reducing the prevalence of blindness through comprehensive eye care services and improving accessibility to eye care facilities across the country. This program has been pivotal in addressing various eye-related issues and enhancing the quality of life for many individuals.
  • • National Programme for Control of Blindness
  • • India in 1976 with the goal of reducing the prevalence of blindness
  • • This program has been pivotal in addressing various eye-related issues
  • • Key aspects of the National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) include:
  • • Key aspects of the National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) include:
  • • Focus on Preventable Blindness : A significant emphasis is placed on preventing blindness caused by conditions that are easily treatable, such as cataract, which is the leading cause of blindness in India. Community Participation: The program encourages community involvement and utilizes a decentralized approach, engaging primary health centers and local healthcare workers to maximize its outreach and impact. Capacity Building: It aims to strengthen the infrastructure for eye care services by upgrading existing facilities, providing training to eye care professionals, and increasing the availability of specialized equipment and materials. Partnerships : The NPCB collaborates with various governmental and non-governmental organizations, including international agencies, to pool resources, share expertise, and expand its reach and effectiveness. Monitoring and Evaluation : Regular monitoring and evaluation mechanisms are in place to assess the program's performance, identify areas for improvement, and ensure the achievement of its targets.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the guidelines laid down by the government of India for organising eye camps?

options.label: A
options.text: Presently SICS & phacoemulsification techniques are recommended

options.label: B
options.text: At least 5 operating surgeons should be present

options.label: C
options.text: Both the eyes should never be operated at one go

options.label: D
options.text: Cases with surgical risks such as diabetes, hypertensives & cardiac problems should not be operated in camps

questions.correct_answer: B. At least 5 operating surgeons should be present
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) At least 5 operating surgeons should be present

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Presently SICS & Phacoemulsification Techniques are Recommended : Small Incision Cataract Surgery (SICS) and Phacoemulsification are modern and efficient techniques for cataract surgery . These methods are indeed recommended for their safety, effectiveness, and relatively quick recovery times.
  • • Option A
  • • Presently SICS & Phacoemulsification Techniques are Recommended
  • • Small Incision Cataract Surgery
  • • Phacoemulsification
  • • modern
  • • efficient techniques for cataract surgery
  • • Option C . Both the Eyes Should Never be Operated at One Go : This is a standard guideline in eye care , especially in camp settings . Operating on both eyes simultaneously increases the risk of complications, including infection. Therefore, it is recommended to operate on one eye at a time.
  • • Option C
  • • Both the Eyes Should Never be Operated at One Go
  • • standard guideline in eye care
  • • camp settings
  • • Option D . Cases with Surgical Risks Such as Diabetes, Hypertensives & Cardiac Problems Should Not be Operated in Camps : This statement is generally true. Patients with systemic conditions like diabetes , hypertension , or cardiac problems are at a higher risk of complications during and after surgery . Such cases typically require more comprehensive pre-operative and post-operative care than what might be available at an eye camp.
  • • Option D
  • • Cases with Surgical Risks Such as Diabetes, Hypertensives & Cardiac Problems Should Not be Operated in Camps
  • • Patients with systemic conditions
  • • diabetes
  • • hypertension
  • • cardiac problems
  • • higher risk of complications during and after surgery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that the requirement of having at least 5 operating surgeons at eye camps is not a standardized guideline by the Government of India , unlike the recommendations for SICS & Phacoemulsification techniques, the practice of not operating on both eyes simultaneously, and the avoidance of operating on high-risk patients in camp settings.
  • ➤ Recognize that the requirement of having at least 5 operating surgeons at eye camps is not a standardized guideline by the Government of India
  • ➤ Ref: pg 487/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: pg 487/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6 th edition

questions.text: Anita, a 32-year-old female patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a complaint of persistent tearing since several months and occasional eye discharge in her left eye. She notices that her left eye frequently waters, especially when she is outdoors or exposed to windy conditions. She has no history of eye trauma or previous eye surgeries. The ophthalmologist suspects a nasolacrimal duct obstruction in the left eye. What is the normal length of the duct involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 12 to 18 mm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. 5 to 10 mm : This length is of the body of the lacrimal sac .
  • • Option A.
  • • 5 to 10 mm
  • • length is of the body
  • • lacrimal sac
  • • Option B. 20 to 25 mm : This is the length of the inferior meatus .
  • • Option B.
  • • 20 to 25 mm
  • • length of the inferior meatus
  • • Option D. 1 to 2 mm: This is the length of the vertical part of the canaliculus .
  • • Option D.
  • • 1 to 2 mm:
  • • length of the vertical part of the canaliculus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal length of the nasolacrimal duct , which drains tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity , is approximately 12 to 18 mm
  • ➤ normal length
  • ➤ nasolacrimal duct
  • ➤ drains tears from the lacrimal sac
  • ➤ nasal cavity
  • ➤ 12 to 18 mm
